Buck.reason: Buck feels betrayed and angry after being kidnapped and mistreated.
Buck is filled with anger and rage towards the men who have mistreated him, and is suffering from hunger and thirst, making him miserable.
Buck is adjusting to his new life and learning quickly, but also experiencing fear and discomfort in the unfamiliar surroundings.
Buck is adapting well to his new environment and learning how to survive, but he still feels the pangs of hunger and has begun to steal food.
Buck is in pain and exhausted from the fight and long journey, but he also surprises himself and Spitz with his fighting prowess.
Buck is exhausted and anxious from his terrifying experience with Dolly, but he is still resolute in his desire for leadership and proving himself as a masterful dog.
Buck feels an ecstatic forgetfulness of living, as he leads the pack, sounding the old wolf-cry, straining after the food that was alive and that fled swiftly before him through the moonlight.
Buck has proven his worth as a lead dog and has successfully brought the mail to Dawson, fulfilling his duty and gaining the respect of his fellow dogs.
Buck is exhausted and his strength is going down.
Buck is bitter and feeling weary.
Buck and his fellow dogs are starving, weak, and overworked, causing them great suffering.
Buck is experiencing genuine passionate love from his new master John Thornton and has progressed significantly in his recovery.
He feels a deep love and loyalty for John Thornton, but his natural wildness still pulls him towards the call of the forest.
Buck successfully saves Thornton and is able to perform an impressive feat of hauling a sled, boosting his confidence.
He loves the hunting, fishing, and wandering through new places with John Thornton and enjoys the gold mining they eventually succeed at.
Buck is living the life he always wanted, fully embracing his wild side, and being praised for it by his human companion John Thornton.
Buck is physically strong and accomplished his mission of taking down the moose, but seems to be plagued by a sense of calamity and the loss of John Thornton.
Buck has finally found his true calling and is now free to answer the call of the wild, running with his wolf brethren.
